docs.lead_paragraph: CAYMANS PACKAGED -- The Cayman Islands Department of Tourism has launched Chillin' 'n' Cayman, a package program available through mid-December from a variety of tour companies; consumers must buy the packages through a travel agent. For example, Gogo Worldwide Vacations has a four-day, three-night package starting at $539 a person, double occupancy, through Sept. 5; the price drops to $499 after that. The price includes round-trip air fare from New York on American Airlines to Grand Cayman; transfers; three nights at the Ambassador Inn, the Sleep Inn or Sunset House, and hotel tax. Those who buy the package also get a discount card good at restaurants and attractions. Information: (800) 327-8777.
docs.abstract: List of some current travel discount offerings (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Mutual fund investors in the United States are moving more money abroad, according to a recent survey by the Gallup Organization for Scudder, Stevens & Clark, which sponsors many funds that invest internationally. The number of American households that invest overseas through funds has risen almost 18 percent since 1994, to 6.7 million, according to the survey. The number that invest solely in funds that stick to American markets has declined 11 percent in the same period.
docs.abstract: Carole Gould (Funds Watch) column discusses recent survey by Gallup Organization for Scudder, Stevens & Clark, which shows mutual fund investors in United States are moving more money abroad; says number of American households that invest overseas through funds has risen almost 18 percent since 1994, to 6.7 million; graph on international funds (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: AFTER leaving a job of 23 years and the wide range of benefits that went with it, Cecilia Felix found herself shopping not long ago for individual long-term disability income insurance. ''I was very concerned I didn't have disability,'' said Mrs. Felix, who was a corporate officer at a national bank before joining a small lease company in Tucson, Ariz. ''I wanted to get it no matter what the price.''

headline.main: A Less Burdensome Path to Safeguard the Future

docs.abstract: Employees seeking long-term disability income insurance can usually save money by recruiting some co-workers and having their employer organize payment of premiums through payroll deductions; program is commonly known as 'list billed' disability insurance--not to be confused with group disability programs; when at least three employees at same company take part, plans are offered at rates generally 10 to 20 percent less than those of comparable individual policy; use of list billing by Cecilia Felix of Tucson, Ariz, discussed; her photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR years, officials have described Medicare and Social Security as the third rail of American politics, untouchable by any politician who wanted to survive. But this year's budget debate suggests that less voltage is flowing through that rail. Congress made sweeping changes in Medicare, encouraging elderly people to enroll in health maintenance organizations and other health plans like those offered by employers. Those changes, plus more being discussed for the future, make clear that America has begun a fundamental re-examination of this immensely popular but hugely expensive program -- just as 75 million baby boomers begin to wonder what will remain of Medicare when they turn 65 in the years after 2010.

headline.main: . . . as Congress Touches the Third Rail and Lives
headline.kicker: The Nation: Clinton Sees History in the Budget-Making . . .

docs.abstract: Recent budget debate suggests Medicare may no longer be so-called third rail of American politics, untouchable by any politician who wishes to survive, as Americans now seem willing to undertake fundamental re-examination of immenseley popular but highly expensive program, just as 75 million baby boomers are wondering what will remain of it when they turn 65 in years after 2010 (M) y

docs.lead_paragraph: The United States economy entered the summer with fresh strength, as an unexpected number of new jobs reduced the nation's unemployment rate to 4.8 percent last month, matching a 23-year low set in May, Government figures showed today. While analysts had predicted that the economy would rebound from a spring slowdown, today's data on jobs, combined with a private report on manufacturing, fanned fears that the rebound might be too strong. Some investors, who have been pushing bond and stock prices higher on the belief that growth is moderate and inflation tame, wondered whether the Federal Reserve would now need to apply the brakes with an increase in interest rates.

headline.main: Report Shows Robust Growth With New Jobs

docs.abstract: US economy strengthens in July, adding 316,000 jobs and lowering unemployment rate to 4.8 percent, matching a 23-year low set in May; National Association of Purchasing Management reports that its overall index rose to 58.6 from 55.7 for the month, while its production index surged by 8.4 points to 64.4; Commerce Department reports that factory orders rose 1.2 percent in June, more than recovering a drop of five-tenths of 1 percent in May; says Americans' income grew six-tenths of 1 percent in June, while spending rose three-tenths of 1 percent; graphs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Older Americans escaped the costly overhaul of their Medicare benefits that some lawmakers in Congress were seeking in Washington's budget negotiations this week. But like younger people with employer-paid or individual health insurance, the elderly are finding it harder to dodge the pressures to sign up for managed care. Attracted by coverage for prescription drugs and other expensive features that the Government does not pay for in traditional fee-for-service Medicare, five million elderly and disabled people, almost one in seven, have joined a health maintenance organization, almost all in the last 12 years.

headline.main: Budget Deal May Push More Elderly Into Managed Care

docs.abstract: Analysis of aspects of Federal budget agreement that will likely speed flow of Medicare patients into managed care; budget calls for higher payments to HMO's in rural areas, which will likely draw in more of the elderly, without cutting generous payments that have allowed urban HMO's to offer broad coverage; patients retain right to return to traditional Medicare, but fee-for-service coverage is becoming every more costly; photos; graphs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Fallout from nuclear blasts at the Nevada Test Site near Las Vegas may have caused 10,000 to 75,000 thyroid cancers, 70 percent of which have not yet been diagnosed, the National Cancer Institute said today. Three-quarters of those cases are expected to develop in people who were younger than 5 at the time of exposure, which occurred mainly in 1952, 1953, 1955 and 1957, the institute said. Medical experts say that about 10 percent of such cancers are fatal.

headline.main: Thousands Have Thyroid Cancer From Atomic Tests

docs.abstract: National Cancer Institute reports that iodine 131 released by nuclear tests in Nevada may have caused 10,000 to 75,000 thyroid cancers, 70 percent of which have not yet been diagnosed; expects three-quarters of those cases to develop in people who were younger than 5 at the time of exposure, which occurred mainly in 1952, 1953, 1955 and 1957; iodine 131 is concentrated in milk of cows and goats that graze on contaminated grass; 24 counties with greatest degree of exposure are in Colorado, Idaho, Montana, South Dakota and Utah; photo; map (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Oxford Health Plans agreed to pay at least $1 million in interest to New York doctors and hospitals on about $238 million in late payments, the New York State Attorney General, Dennis C. Vacco, said yesterday. The agreement settles an investigation by Mr. Vacco into the health maintenance organization's delays in making payments to New York hospitals and doctors.

headline.main: Oxford to Pay Extra On Late Payments

docs.abstract: Oxford Health Plans agrees to pay at least $1 million in interest to New York doctors and hospitals on about $238 million in late payments (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: When President Clinton signed the welfare bill last year, he said it was ''far from perfect,'' and pledged to ''change what is wrong.'' Slim as the odds seemed then, Mr. Clinton largely got his way in the budget agreement that both chambers of Congress have just approved. He paid a price in acquiescing to tax cuts for wealthier Americans, analysts on the left and right say, but he won major concessions in blunting some of the welfare law's toughest provisions.

headline.main: In Budget Bill, President Wins Welfare Battle

docs.abstract: Federal budget agreement marks success of Pres Clinton's efforts to blunt tough provisions in last year's welfare reform, although he has in exchange accepted tax cuts for wealthier Americans; Clinton could not raise food-stamp allotments in higher-cost cities like New York and won only $1.5 billion of $4.8 billion he sought for all food stamp spending; he did not alter basic change in welfare system, which shifts control to states and ends cradle-to-grave entitlements; bill does let stand Labor Department order that welfare recipients who take state jobs get minimum wage; legal immigrants who lived in US as of last August 22 remain eligible for Supplemental Security Income and Medicaid; employers will get tax credits on salaries paid to welfare recipients they hire, for first two years; Congress also approves $3 billion over two years for job-seeking aid for single, able-bodied adults, but states may now exempt 15 percent of this group, which critic Douglas Besharov calls 'hush money' for big-city mayors; Congress also allots $24 billion over five years to extend Medicaid to half of nation's ten million children who lack health insurance, with part of cost paid by increased cigarette taxes; some disabled children will also retain Medicaid (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: As her three boys were returning from school one Friday in March, Charlene Prowse, who works nights at a convenience store here, awakened from her day's sleep. Mrs. Prowse, 31 and robust despite a battle six years ago with ovarian cancer, stepped into the hallway of the family's home in this working-class suburb of Little Rock. Then she collapsed. ''Mom was on the floor,'' said Cory, her 8-year-old son, who rushed in from the porch with his brother Steven, 7. Her husband, Randal Sr., 40, said: ''She was shaking, staring into space. I started giving her C.P.R.''

headline.main: Illness Is Turning Into Financial Catastrophe for More of the Uninsured

docs.abstract: Sudden illness has turned into financial catastrophe for many thousands of Americans who work but do not have health insurance; Charlene Prowse and her husband are forced into bankruptcy in Arkansas because of $8,000 in medical bills, one of many such examples; photo; 17 million of nation's 23 million uninsured adults work full time, earning too little to pay for insurance and too much for Medicaid; economy, perversely, bears some of blame, lifting millions off welfare and unemployment rolls but creating mostly low-wage service and retail jobs; 64 percent of employers provide subsidized insurance, down from 60 percent decade ago (M)
